Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Copepod life history and lipid strategy in a changing Arctic - A new trait-based approach to data synthesis, modeling, and end-to-end integration
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many people have argued that the diminishing summer Arctic sea ice extent will result in enhanced growth of small aquatic plants and, consequently, the small marine animals (zooplankton) that feed upon these plants. These animals are the preferred prey of larger animals that are important sources of subsistence and commercial harvest for local Arctic residents. This proposed project explores the idea that the nutritional value of the zooplankton may be altered as their numbers and total mass increase. Thus, predicting the impact of an increase in zooplankton may not be as straightforward as previously assumed.

This proposal is motivated by the hypothesis that the impact of future climate change on high-latitude planktivores, such as seabirds, fish, and bowhead whales, will come as much through changes in their prey quality (individual size and lipid content) as through changes in their prey biomass?with decreases in quality often accompanying and outweighing increases in biomass. To explore this hypothesis, the PIs will develop and apply a new kind of model that links climate forcing to impacts on planktivores via the life-history patterns of large zooplankton. A set of coordinated regional and large-scale model applications will examine specific, local versions of the central hypothesis as it applies to calanoid copepods and their predators, in the process refining the model, ensuring its cross-region portability, and also integrating a number of rich US and European zooplankton datasets for the first time.

The project will initiate and expand an array of collaborations among researchers in the US and Denmark. These collaborations include capacity-building and a postdoc exchange with the Centre for Ocean Life at the Technical University of Denmark, the leading center of trait-based marine research. Furthermore, using leveraged support from the IGERT Program on Ocean Change at the University of Washington, the PI will visit the Greenland Climate Research Centre (Nuuk) to work with M. Simon and other colleagues on formulating a new, student-centered collaboration on indigenous seafood security and human dimensions of climate change. This is also an opportunity to share early model results with zooplankton, fisheries, and marine mammal researchers there, and develop new applied research directions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate impacts on fish, birds, and mammals in high-latitude regions come via a wide variety of pathways, making prediction of future trends - even their direction, let alone their magnitude - extremely difficult, even where trends in the underlying environmental drivers are well understood. A fundamental problem is a mismatch between what oceanographic, climate-timescale studies tend to emphasize (total primary production or perhaps total zooplankton production) and what higher-trophic-level researchers actually need: information on prey quality (species composition, individual size, energy content). This project developed and tested a new mathematical model designed to to serve as a "translation layer" between oceanographic projections (phytoplankton, water temperature, transport patterns) and higher-trophic-level impacts (fish and fisheries, seabirds, and marine mammals).

The Coltrane (Copepod Life history Traits and Adaptation to New Environments) model is a mathematical framework for layering multiple levels of mesozooplankton biology on top of oceanographic models. It is focused on calanoid copepods, which generally dominate the large zooplankton biomass in Arctic seas, although ongoing work aims to extend it to other large zooplankton groups (such as krill) as well. Coltrane resolves the life-history of individuals (growth, juvenile development, adult size, starvation limits); 2) population dynamics (the balance between gains through egg production, and losses through predation); and 3) community composition (the range of viable trait combinations under particular environmental conditions). It combines ideas from the 'optimal annual routine' tradition in animal ecology with the more recent 'emergent communities' tradition in marine plankton modelling.

The model was constructed based on a review of 45 lab studies of copepod growth and development, which identified two species-specific strategy traits that control body size and to a large extent life history: a relative development rate (does this species reach maturity slowly or quickly, relative to other copepods with the same thermal optimum?) and a relative growth rate (does this species grow slowly or quickly for its size?).

In a simplified, global-scale model experiment, the model correctly predicts life strategies in large Calanus spp. ranging from multiple generations per year to multiple years per generation. In an experiment representing Disko Bay, West Greenland, the model predicts trait correlations along a body size spectrum that closely matches local populations of three coexisting Calanus spp.: small animals (adult size ∼100 μg C) reproducing once per year timed to match each year's phytoplankton bloom, through large ones (adult size >1000 μgC) with a multiple-year life cycle, which reproduce months before the spring bloom. These are key steps toward generating realistic zooplankton communities within numerical model systems.

Coltrane is currently being applied, through follow-on UK- and Norwegian-funded projects, to large-scale changes in the high Arctic linked to sea-ice loss; the response of the food web to warm-cold year variation in the Pacific, from Oregon to Alaska; and zooplankton in the Southern Ocean from the West Antarctic Peninsula to South Georgia Island.


Last Modified: 01/02/2019
Modified by: Julie E Keister
